captions.text:
Shh... I've snuck into minutephysics' studio
to explain how a wing actually works

Hang on, something doesn't feel right.
Ah, that's better.

Now everyone knows that a wing generates lift
due to its characteristic shape

Since air travels farther over top of the
wing, it must go faster than the air underneath

so that both streams meet up simultaneously
at the trailing edge

And according to Bernoulli's principle, faster
flowing air exerts less pressure than the

slower air beneath the wing
This pressure difference creates an upward

force -- lift.
Job done. Right? Nope

This simple explanation taught in many textbooks
and classrooms has obvious problems

Like how could a plane fly upside down?
Some planes like the Wright brothers' had

nearly flat wings. So presumably air would
travel the same speed over both sides and

there would be no lift
Plus experiments show that air streams don't

meet up at the back of the wing. Air over
the top goes significantly faster, reaching

the trailing edge first.
So how does a wing actually generate lift?

Well the key is the wing must deflect air
downwards

This can be achieved using asymmetric or cambered
air foils

Or by increasing the angle of attack
Air under the wing is deflected down

And by the coanda effect
air above the wing is guided along its surface

and down as well
Since the air is slowed and deflected down

by the wing,
it pushes the wing up and back. Lift, and

drag.
This is in accordance with Newton's Third

Law of Motion
But hang on, if you can explain lift only

using the deflection of air and Newton's laws,
then the Bernoulli explanation must be completely

wrong
Well, no,

air over the top of the wing does go faster
than air beneath, creating a pressure difference

that generates lift
Then this Newtonian explanation is unnecessary

rubbish and the original explanation was right!
That's not true either. The original explanation

incorrectly assumed that air over and under
the wing must reconnect at the trailing edge,

and there was no mention of deflecting air
down.

Each explanation, done correctly, completely
accounts for the lift generated by a wing.

They're just two different ways of looking
at the same thing.

So next time someone brings up the standard
misconception, you can tell them that explanation

just doesn't fly.
And if you liked that, you've gotta check

out MinutePhysics. I've got total respect
for a guy who does this every week.

Sincerely, a collection of particles known
as Derek.

title: How Does A Wing Actually Work?

comments.text:
This is actually an incomplete explanation. The greater velocity along the 
top, in short, is created by vorticity around the airfoil. The trailing 
edge of the wing creates a vortex and conservation of amgular momentum 
dictates that another vortex must be created in the opposite spin. This 
vortex around the airfoil causes air to move faster along the top.

The math is pretty complicated, but there are good walkthroughs online.﻿

comments.author: kezzako

comments.text:
+MrZsc Planes can stop by reducing the power from the engine. The air 
constantly creates a force ''drag'' against the airplane, slowing it. 
Without enough engine power, the drag overpowers the forward force, slowing 
the airplane until it stops. There also are systems (air-brakes) to create 
more drag on command thus slowing the airplane even more. There also is a 
system which can make a turbine engine (engine used on big airplanes) apply 
its force in the opposite direction, slowing the airplane or making it go 
backwards.

+MrZsc No, gliders don't use wind to gain propulsion. They could work 
without any wind. What they do use is gravitational energy. When they start 
to fall, they pick up downwards speed which could then be turned into 
forwards speed. This means to go far in a glider, you'd need a lot of 
gravitational potential energy (eg. height.) So yeah, you don't really need 
an active propulsion system to be able to fly.

comments.text:
For the math people out there, Bernoullli's principle is what you get when 
you do a force balance on a infinitesimally small volume element of the 
fluid (assumed inviscid). You would use differential calculus to express 
this. Newton's 3rd law is what you get when you do a force balance over the 
control volume around the system of interest, using integral calculus. They 
are two expressions each describing the same physical situation, consistent 
with each other. 

Bernoulli explanation: 
Bernoulli's principle tells us that whenever you have a velocity change 
along a streamline, it will be accompanied by a pressure change. This is 
well confirmed experimentally. And indeed you do have a velocity change as 
the air passes above and below the wing, and indeed you do have pressure 
changes. Pressure x area = Force, and that force acts on the wing. 
Bernoulli's principle is indeed relevant to producing lift. 

Newton's 3rd law explanation: 
As a consequence of that low pressure on top of the wing, downward momentum 
is imparted to the air flowing above that low pressure zone. The derivative 
of momentum with respect to time is force. So we have the wing imparting a 
downward force to the air, and by Newton's 3rd law, the air is imparting an 
upward force to the wing. 

IMPORTANT -- the force arising from these two effects (pressure and 
momentum change of air) are not additive. It's the same force. These are 
two different ways of expressing the result of the SAME PHYSICAL PROCESS 
taking place. Bernoulli Principle is a force balance at microscopic scale. 
Newton's 3rd law is a force balance at the macroscopic scale. Both apply, 
both are consistent, both give you approximately the same answer. 

But HERE is where the common explanation using Bernoulli's Principle often 
goes wrong. It is often said that the air goes faster over the top of the 
wing because it is more curved, so it has longer to travel in order to meet 
up with the air below the wing that it was separated from. WRONG! First, 
there is no constraint that a parcel of air divided at the leading edge 
must meet up at the trailing edge. Second, aerodynamicists have known for a 
very long time from wind tunnel testing that the air traveling over a wing 
producing lift will always reach the trailing edge first. It never does 
"meet back up" with the air below. This is true for an airfoil or just a 
simple flat plate. Third, just consider some examples -- aerobatic 
airplanes have symmetrical airfoils with the same curvature top and bottom. 
Hang gliders just have a singe layer of fabric, thus the same distance of 
travel above or below. The Wright Flyer has a very thin cambered wing where 
the distance along the wing surface above and below is the same. All of 
these wings produce lift. How? 

Well that question gets more complicated. It has to do with the generation 
of a low pressure zone above the wing (which results in the change in 
velocity viz a viz Bernoulli) and circulation theory. You can look that 
stuff up if you want to dig into it further. ﻿
comments.author: ILLove Trance

comments.text:
+ILLove Trance   While you covered it VERY nicely, you are a bit above the 
average YouTuber's level.  (;-)...I will, however, pick a few nits with 
you....1) Saying simply: "a velocity change ....accompanied by a pressure 
change" avoids any cause and effect statement and, I feel ,helps support 
the misunderstanding that fluid speed causes lower pressure which violates 
Newton's messages to us, as well as reality.  Fluid (a mass) is accelerated 
by pressure diffrences (a force) and this is a net force from a high to a 
low pressure region....wind ... and it explains air accelerating around the 
leading edge and over the top both radially and tangentially (the curved 
path and the speed increase).  Leaf blower and TP demos of Entrainment 
abound on the web pretending to be Bernoulli's "Principle" demos. ...2) 
Then, I feel the following two comments are contradictory  A) "As a 
consequence of that low pressure on top of the wing, downward momentum is 
imparted to the air flowing above....NOTE "consequence of"   B)  "two 
different ways of expressing the result of the SAME PHYSICAL PROCESS "...I 
maintain that "A" gives a cause and effect relationship (by virtue of 
the phrase "a consequence of ") between the pressure difference and the 
downwash.  i.e pressure difference causes the acceleration of the 
downwashed air. Something (a force) must accelerate that mass of air.  I 
prefer to make this distinction because it serves to support the 
universality of Newton's teachings.... However, "B" calls this the same 
force when they are the two "opposite and equal" forces called out by what 
we call Newton's Third law.  I don't consider them the same force, but 
components of the whole explanation of lift. ...Analogy: I push myself up 
with my foot on some sand on a dune and sand is pushed down - they act in 
opposite directions. ...To summarize lift,  "stuff happens" around wing 
causing pressure difference which results in an upward force on the 
wing...this accellerates a mass of air downward which is from a force 
downard.   If F=MA is indeed universal, then these must be two separate 
forces because they are causing two accelerations of two masses.  One is 
countering the acceleratoin of gravity and the other accelerating a mas of 
air downward.. ...You may call that a preference, but keeping the forces 
separate allows easier identification of the results of two of the parts ( 
lift and downwash) of the whole story. ...I can easily relate your 
"microscopic scale" to my "stuff "happening around the wing, and your 
"macroscopic scale" to Newton #3 which I like to refer to as  "The 
Phenomenon of Paired Forces"....and that they are both different, but 
important  parts of the entire story....Granted that without the first 
force (me pusing on the sand) there is no second force (sand movement) , 
but I think it is more instructive to talk about them as separate forces.  
...Comments invited?-- ScienceAdviserStevehttp://www.challenger.org/

comments.text:
OOPS not Coanda.

Coanda only exists (if at all) in accelerated flow like Upper Surface 
Blowing not in normal flow.

Upper surface air follows the upper surface because it has no choice. Think 
of the wing under water (water and air behave the same way) -now how does 
that impact on your explanation? Viscosity and static pressure cause the 
flow to remain attached unless the angular velocity reaches an angle where 
the air cannot turn the corner at the leading edge. This then results in 
turbulent flow known as a stall.

Also it is not the relative speed of upper and lower surface air that 
caused the pressure difference-this is an effect. The pressure difference 
is caused by the lower surface pushing the air forwards and downwards 
causing a slight pressure increase and the upper surface air bending the 
air downwards. As the upper air turns the corner it is drawn into the 
pressure shadow or leeward side of the wing and this causes a slight 
pressure drop.

Pressure changes are the result of lift production- which is caused by 
turning a fluid. They are not the cause.That is why flat wings work 
perfectly well at lower AOA.﻿

The air traveling over the top of the wing tries to continue at the same 
speed and direction, as stated in Newton's first law of motion. That is 
what causes a vacuum to form on top of the wing, and that vacuum pulls the 
air down while it pulls the wing upward. Bernoulli's principle is a 
misconception. If Bernoulli was correct, lift could be achieved in a 
canister, causing a force not in an "equal and opposite reaction", (as 
stated in Newton's third law of motion), but in an equal and perpendicular 
reaction.﻿

+oktal3700   I disagree,  Jane Sheols has it pretty much correct (I 
 wouldn't say "vacuum" just lower pressure).   In order for the air to 
curve around the leading edge and uppper surface, a force must be exerted

comments.author: Observ45er

comments.text:
Your understanding of Bernoulli's principle is a misconception, but the 
principle itself is not. The air particles don't all start off going in the 
same direction. On average, there is a trend towards a certain direction, 
but the individual particles are constantly bumping off one another and 
jostling in all different directions. That's pressure. As the average speed 
of the particles increases, so more of them must be following the average 
direction, with less jostling. Bernoulli's principle is consistent with 
Newton's laws of motion. More than that, it is a *consequence* of Newton's 
laws. A vacuum doesn't pull things towards it; things are pushed towards a 
vacuum by the higher pressure on their other side.

One of the reasons (as far as we know, there are 4 reasons, all helping to 
create Lift upwards, but the exact % of each of these reasons in the 
creation of Lift is today unknown) that the Airfoil creates Lift is the 
pressure difference between the top and bottom of the airfoil and this 
pressure difference is created when the air above the airfoil must speed up 
due to the Ventouri effect.

It does NOT speed up in order to reach the end of the airfoil at the same 
time as the air flowing beneath. The air that goes above the airfoil 
reaches the end of the airfoil faster than the air that travels below it.

Look up the Ventouri effect and Bernoullis theorem for a better 
understanding of this.﻿

comments.text:
This is where a symmetric airfoil comes in. Most acrobatic planes have a 
symmetric airfoil. Meaning the airfoil at 0 degrees angle of attack does 
not generate lift. So the lift generated is only "generated" by the angle 
of attack. So in both situations, if you keep your nose "up" (wether you're 
up side down or not) you will generate lift.

From 2D airfoil theory. (note 2D, this theory does not apply to finite 
wings, but it still gives an idea of how things work) the lift coefficient 
of a wing at a certain angle of attack is given to be 2 * pi * alpha (in 
radians). Then if you multiply this value by 0.5 * rho (density) * 
V^2(velocity)*S (wing surface area) you get the lift force produced by the 
wing.

Source: I'm an Aerospace Engineering Bachelor student at the Delft 
University of technology

comments.text:
There is a fundamental issue with this explanation and that is the 
assumption that the Bernoulli theorem (and it is simply a mathematical 
construct that describes a physical phenomenon) "causes" the lift.  No, it 
does not cause the lift.  In a dynamically closed system, a fluid moving 
into a region of lower pressure must accelerate because it is moving down a 
pressure gradient.  Thus, each fluid parcel is experiencing an unbalanced 
force, but its resistance to that acceleration "pushes back" at the higher 
pressure, maintaining that pressure gradient.  

Now, when the air passes under the wing, the streamlines of fluid parcels 
are deflected downwards.  This is because the underside of the wing 
directly deflects the adjacent fluid parcels downward.  These exert a 
pressure on incoming parcels that causes them to slow down (accelerate in a 
forward direction, or against the direction of flow).  Their resistance to 
this acceleration generates the pressure gradient under the wing and the 
pressure gradient generates the acceleration.  Reciprocal cause and effect. 
 Most people can intuitively understand why the air passing under the wing 
must be deflected downwards and why it must slow down.

However, the "cloud" of increased pressure under the wing also extends 
slightly forward of the wing, as well.  Fluid parcels approaching the 
leading edge that are destined to pass over the wing are initially 
deflected upwards by that "cloud" of increased pressure extending below and 
in front of the wing.  As they pass over the leading edge and top side of 
the wing, the individual air molecules would continue in a straight line up 
and back, but air is a fluid and collisions between air molecules are 
common.  Thus, the air that has been deflected upwards is now being forced 
by the air above it to accelerate back downwards to follow the contour of 
the upper surface of the wing.  That air's inertial resistance to that 
downward acceleration causes it to form a "bubble" of low pressure above 
the wing and that same "bubble" of low pressure causes the acceleration 
that the air's inertia resists.  Again, reciprocal cause-and-effect.  

The Bernoulli theorem is a mathematical construct that describes the way 
that fluid parcels must accelerate as they move from high to low pressure 
(and vice-versa), but it does not, in and of itself, explain *why*﻿

comments.text:
Air is accelerated down from being deflected from the underside of the 
wing. It also bends down through Coanda Effect trying to follow the curved 
top side of the wing, and is accelerated down from there. Whichever way you 
want to analyze or interpret what happens locally to the air parcels 
directly above and below the wing, the net result is that air *is* 
accelerated down behind the wing. Lift may be viewed as a reaction to the 
downward acceleration that was applied to the air mass.

comments.text:
+John Ellis RE: However, he does not talk about why the shape causes air to 
move more quickly across the top."
...
Yes, he does not explain why.
...
Because he is not providing a comprehensive explanation, but a simplified 
version ... and ...
Perhaps because it actually does not travel more quickly" over the top as 
most folks think it does. Please note the careful analysis of the wind 
tunnel images and text on the 5 th page of this:
http://219sqn.aafc.org.au/Flight/Simple%20Aerodynamics-How%20planes%20fly.pdf
 
...
This *is* one of the better summary videos.
...
Everyone has their own pet aspect of this phenonomenon and puts all their 
eggs in that one basket as though the other significant things (causes & 
phenomena) going on around the wing are minor, or irrelevant.
Yes, There is a difference in speeds between the air near top and bottom, 
and pressure differences and downwash as the result of the pressure 
differences and a very large mass of air above the wing contributes a great 
deal to the downwash (which he also ignores).  However, all these are part 
of the explanation and without them all, one must simplify and summarize 
somewhere...  and he does.
...
The only error I see around 1:20, and already commented on, is that he 
envokes Coanda, which is technically incorrect.   While similar, Coanda is 
in relation to high speed jets, or sheets of flow that are directed along a 
convex surface, not the ordinary flow around a moving surface.  I believe 
Bentley's above paper mentions that as well.  If that one doesn't, the most 
recent one (2015 linked from his site) does.
...
His comment around 2:00 that "each explanation, if done correctly, 
completely  accounts for the lift" is misleading because each explanation *as 
commonly stated*, is incorrect and/or incomplete.  Each [Bernoulli's Law 
and Newton's Laws] must be applied at the correct points, and in correct 
COMBINATION, to completely explain lift.  They actually are both required 
aspects of a complete explanation.
...
Lift is one of the subjects most dominated by the Dunning-Kruger effect
...
Cheers, ScienceAdviserSteve
http://www.challenger.org/

authoritative information on-line if anyone wants to look for it, as I 
have.  I have also communicated with a couple of knowledgable folks.

 My claim is that the math we use in science is a *model* for the natural 
phenomenon.  The math is not the phenomenon itself.  The phenomenon can be 
described in relatively simple terms as long as one understands what we 
call basic physics and Newton's Laws.  (keeping in mind that Bernoulli is 
another manifestation of Newton's laws); and please do not assume from this 
that My explanation is the common "it's all Newton" (Downwash)  explanation 
seemingly given by some who don't understand it all.

While I'd rather not here, I believe I can give a 90% correct explanation 
of the phenomena around a wing to a high school physics student and never 
have to use N-S and still account for the bulk of the phenomena.  Radial 
accelerations, pressure differences and Newton's third Law do a pretty good 
job of accounting for what is going on with no violations of well known 
physical laws. I have passed this by some experts with success.    The 
references I have posted many times are good examples of similar 
explanations. (Eastwell, Weltner, and Anderson & Eberhardt and McLean).

surface has an effect on a considerable amount air further above the wing 
that is also part of the air that is accelerated downward behind the wing.

lift if produced by a force on the bottom of the wing being greater than 
that on the top. (action reaction)
air exerts a force (Pressure) on the top and bottom equally while no air is 
flowing.
when air is flowing past a flat piece of steel inline (0°) with the flow 
there is no change of direction of the air and no acceleration, and no 
pressure differential between top and bottom.
add +1° to the plate relative to the airflow and now we have a requirement 
and an allowance for the air to change direction and accelerate to the 
newly formed void (said respectively)
the change of direction requirement will cause a pressure increase as 
collisions and airs viscosity cause a back log of air particles trying to 
pass under the wing. this is a small fraction of the overall pressure 
differential that will result in the total lifting force created.
the allowance of air particles to fill the void on the top part of 
the steel plate will result in less collisions with each other, and since 
air is always wanting to separate (while any air pressure is in play) that 
air will separate filling that void. this results in
a/ less time for the air particles to impact the upper surface due to speed 
past the steel plate. and due to that surface being continually out of 
reach by the time that air particle reaches were the surface was just a 
moment ago.
OK the surface is not quite out of reach, well not at subsonic levels at 
least, but the effect can be well visualised this way. there are still 
impacts between the upper surface and the air particles (thus there is 
still air pressure felt by the upper surface), but the number of impacts is 
greatly reduced(air pressure is greatly reduced), so much so that the 
greater majority of the pressure differential caused during the production 
of lift is from the effect of less pressure on the upper surface.

it should be noted that when one says upper surface it is generally the 
side that does not present its surface directly to the airflow, that is the 
side where the air must change direction to be able to stay in contact with 
it.
the underside will have its surface presented to the airflow, but generally 
the air particle that was inline with a section of that will be changed in 
direction due to the air in front of it being in the way so to say. but

Entirely Newtonian-based wings could work. For every force there is an 
equal and opposite reaction, thus the downward force on the angled aileron 
creates an equally powerful upward force that moves the craft to the rear 
and upwards. This rearward movement causes the aircraft to slow down and 
travel upwards. The correctly-explained Bernoulli's Principle and how it 
behaves in flight still only accounts for a small amount of force generated.

A totally symmetrical wing could thus work, despite having nothing to do 
with the Bernoulli Principle. However, it would require a great amount of 
thrust to generate said lift without the Bernoulli Principle.

comments.text:
+corisco tupi +Gordon Freeman That's a bit rude corisco. He is however 
incorrect. Lift is actually the result of a force applied to anything to 
make it rise. The exact explanation that causes an aircraft to fly is 
something like Derek spoke about in his video. When air hits the front of a 
wing it splits. The air just below the wing increases in pressure slightly 
due to this split and the angle with which the wing is laid in comparison 
to direction of motion through the air. At the same time, the air above the 
wing is also being split which DOES increase the pressure above the wing 
slightly for a moment (at the very front of the wing) however since the 
wing is slightly angled upward, there is a pressure drop caused by the 
cavity formed from an essential plank cutting into the air. The space 
behind this plane (the wing) is essentially devoid of air (not really) and 
so the air and the wing its-self want to rush into it. The air rushing into 
it is the cause of the low pressure. The wing wanting to rush into it is 
what produces *lift from a wing*. It infact wants to "doubly" rush into it 
due to the high pressure below the wing.

A Harrier jump jet can *produce lift* by directing its *thrust* downward.

It can also *produce lift* using it's conventional wings which require a 
certain maintained velocity for sustained *flight*. The *thrust* on a 
Harrier can be used to main this velocity to allow for the wings to produce 
lift.

(To be honest i'm not exactly correct here. Aircraft will actually not 
continue to rise at level flight. There is a balance between the force of 
gravity and the lift produced by the wing at level flight. However, once 
you angle the wing into the air more vertically you can infact produce more 
lift but this isn't essentially how aircraft climb either. An aircraft 
actually climbs in altitude by firstly maintaining its angle of attack or 
pitch entirely by the stability caused by the wing in the first place and 
secondly by the thrust of the aircraft now being vectored at an angle 
pushing the aircraft along this angled "line" higher. However even if you 
cut the engines on an aircraft it may still climb at the cost of its 
airspeed. For example, at a 45 degree angle an aircraft that has been 
climbing which suddenly cuts its engines will lose airspeed rather quickly 
due to gravity and drag (some of this drag is directly converted into 
flight stability). It will however continue to climb on that angle so long 
as the wings have airspeed giving it "flight stability". Once the aircraft 
drops below this speed, the wings will no longer be effective and the 
aircraft will begin to fall like a big flat rock. (Horizontal stabilizers, 
more accurately known as a tailplane [or lateral neck plane] can be 
correctly used to constantly provide the accurate type of force required to 
turn a falling rock into a flying aircraft once again. Most aircraft are 
designed front heavy so that they resultantly fall nose down resulting in 
effective airspeed at the wings, resulting in stability which can then 
cause effective usage of tail or neck planes to slowly convert the 
aircrafts flight path to something horizontal once again)

comments.author: benjamin rathjen

comments.text:
This seems like an incomplete explanation, and it doesn't describe 
Bernoulli's principle adequately. Bernoulli's principle never says why the 
air speeds up, just that it does so with an associated decrease in 
pressure. In the case of a wing, the air speeds up because it in a sense 
passes through a restriction created by the camber of the wing, like in a 
venturi. Visualized two dimensionally, the camber of the wing forms the 
bottom of the restriction, and the airflow not affected by the wing forms 
the top. This explains why a cambered wing creates lift even at zero angle 
of attack. In fact, camber has such a profound effect on the performance of 
a wing, that certain extremely thick and highly cambered wings can offset 
some of their induced drag by creating a lift vector angled towards the 
direction of flight.

I also feel that the video oversimplifies what happens when the angle of 
attack increases, only addressing the increase in Newtonian lift, the 
downward deflection of air. Increasing the angle of attack also decreases 
the size of the theoretical restriction, thus speeding up the airflow over 
the top of the wing. This explains how a flat wing like the Wright 
Brothers' was able to fly. Camber is not needed to induce Bernoullian lift 
when the angle of attack is anything but zero.

Overall I think that this explanation is pointed in the right direction, 
but it's still inadequate to the point that it unfortunately further 
contributes to an improper understanding of lift. It correctly addresses 
the misconception that two air-streams separated at the leading edge must 
meet at the trailing edge, and it introduces little known Newtonian lift, 
but it really is a vast oversimplification and gross under-explanation of 
the contributions of Bernoullian lift. Yes they both exist in wing 
aerodynamics and are complexly interrelated, but they don't explain the 
same thing.﻿

comments.text:
+grah55 I assume you mean canard surfaces? (Saab 37 Viggen, Burt Rutan's 
VariEze and Long-Ez, etc)  Yes, they do exactly the same thing, but since 
they are forward of the center of gravity they are rigged to produce 
positive, not negative lift. But the principle is the same: an unintended 
decrease in speed, for instance, lowers the canard lift, which lowers the 
nose which increases airspeed. The canard configuration is actually more 
efficient as airplanes with this configuration need less wing area (hence 
less drag) to lift the same weight at the same speed. To be totally fair 
though, in your Concorde example, those are not true canards but nose 
strakes. Contrary to canards, they have no direct contribution to 
longitudinal stability. They are placed to control flow at specific 
airplane parts in high angles of attack and are usually not part of the 
original design, being added later usually during flight testing. 
Interestingly, one of Concorde's early design configurations (Bristol 198, 
later dropped in favor of the shape we have come to know) was a true canard 
design.

comments.author: grah55

comments.text:
*+grah55* - The "lateral wings" or horizontal stabilizers are needed for 
longitudinal stability. Aircraft have their center of gravity ahead (more 
forward) than the center of lift, making them nose-heavy. Horizontal 
stabilizers produce negative lift pushing the tail down (nose up). The 
beauty of this setup is that it is naturally self-stabilizing: any 
 decrease in airspeed will make the stabilizer produce less negative lift, 
allowing the nose to drop, which increases speed again. Conversely, an 
increase in speed will increase the downforce on the stabilizer pulling the 
nose up, thus reducing speed. This is why airplanes fly hands-off at 
constant airspeed - the airplane is always actively seeking to fly at  the 
trimmed airspeed by its own, regardless of pilot input. *That* is what the 
"lateral wings" (horizontal stabilizers) are for.

comments.author: Duncan Herbst

comments.text:
+Andrew Delashaw read more carefully.   He said that goes faster because it 
has "farther to travel."   That's wrong, and this video above is correct. 
 D. Herbst's mistake is debunked by Cambridge University in this short 
video:  Airflow across a wing  For lots more about D. Herbst's error, see 
the NASA site about the Incorrect lift theory called "longer path" or 
"equal transit" http://www.grc.nasa.gov/WWW/K-12/airplane/wrong1.html

So *why* do the bits of air above the wing vastly outrace the bits of air 
flowing below?   It's because of Circulation Theory:  air has inertia, and 
the back half of the wing causes air to bend downward and flow smoothly off 
in a diagonal direction.  For air to bend like this, the air below the wing 
must be at relative higher pressure than air above.  This causes the 
difference in speed.

So, the "equal transit" incorrect theory gets it backwards, and actually 
the difference in speed is caused by the difference in pressure.

comments.text:
There are infinitely-many kinematically-possible flows around a wing. The 
reason why the flow travels faster above the wing is because this is the 
only type of flow in which the flow leaves the trailing edge cleanly (Kutta 
condition). We take it for granted that a flow should leave the sharp edge 
at a specific angle, but really that is because viscosity constantly 
enforces this requirement. Without viscosity, the flow would be entirely 
different.

Jean-Claude Van Damne  synthesized the concept better than Bernouilli or 
Newton did.He said: "I am fascinated by air. If you remove the air from the 
sky, all the birds would fall to the ground. And all the planes, too."  
...Then he added :"and so would do all the  fish an submarines if you 
remove the water"﻿
